title: The Piracy Line
preview: A tanker seized in international waters tests how far U.S. power - and maritime law - can bend.
body:
The footage arrived before the legal arguments did. A rope ladder swinging in the rotor wash, armed American personnel dropping onto the deck of a fully loaded supertanker in the dark Caribbean. The imagery carried its own gravity even before Washington or Caracas attached their explanations. What mattered immediately—and still matters now—is that the boarding took place outside Venezuelan territorial waters, in the legally ambiguous zone where power often matters more than law. Guyana, whose flag the ship claimed to fly, stated plainly that the _Skipper_ was in international waters and had fraudulently used its registration¹. That one fact knocked the center of gravity away from Venezuela’s sovereignty claim and into the contested space of stateless shipping, sanctions enforcement, and high-seas jurisdiction.

**A seizure in international waters is not piracy by definition, but it can look close enough to raise every historical alarm bell.**

The Maduro government called the raid “shameless piracy”², and the political potency of that word is obvious. Piracy evokes predation, not process. The problem for Caracas is that international law’s definition hinges on “private ends”—the acts of non-state actors seeking personal gain. This was a uniformed, state-directed operation³. Whatever else it may be, it is not piracy under UNCLOS. But legality is only one dimension; legitimacy is another. A government that has been battered by sanctions, squeezed out of global finance, and forced to sell its crude at a discount will not draw fine distinctions between a SEAL team and a pirate crew. The symbolism cuts deeper than the statute.

What the United States asserts is something more bureaucratic, if no less forceful: that the _Skipper_, previously sanctioned as part of an Iran–Venezuela oil-for-cash network⁴ and now deemed stateless, was subject to a federal seizure warrant tied to terrorism-related forfeiture⁵. From that vantage point, the logic is almost mechanical. A ship already blacklisted by Treasury, carrying sanctioned crude, allegedly tied to Hezbollah financing, using a false flag, drifting through a region patrolled by Operation Southern Spear⁶: the pieces assemble themselves into a template Washington has been refining for nearly a decade.

**Sanctions can explain a seizure; they cannot, on their own, justify it under international law.**

UNCLOS is explicit in what it allows states to do on the high seas: interdict pirates, slave traders, unauthorized broadcasters, and stateless vessels⁷. The United States leans heavily on that last category. Stateless ships occupy the least protected corner of maritime law. Any nation may board them; none has exclusive jurisdiction. In theory, that gives Washington its cleanest footing. In practice, the move still exports U.S. domestic policy onto international waters without a U.N. mandate, raising the same concerns that followed Britain’s 2019 seizure of the Iranian tanker _Grace 1_ near Gibraltar⁸. Then, as now, a sanctions regime meant for a political adversary spilled into the global commons.

History is full of moments where seizures like this become accelerants. Libya’s rebel-held _Morning Glory_ in 2014⁹, Iran’s retaliatory grabs of British and Greek tankers in 2019 and 2022¹⁰, Britain’s brief custody of _Grace 1_, and America’s quiet diversion of multiple Iranian crude shipments¹¹ all demonstrate the same unstable pattern: once economic warfare migrates onto the water, each interdiction invites another. The danger is not just escalation—it is normalization. Once a major power proves willing to physically seize commercial vessels outside its territorial reach, that precedent rarely stays in the drawer.

**The most consequential seizures are never the first ones—they are the ones others feel empowered to copy.**

Venezuela’s domestic stakes are not abstract. Oil revenue is the state’s oxygen, and the country had finally clawed back to roughly 900,000 barrels per day in November¹² after years of collapse. One interdicted tanker can be dismissed as an isolated enforcement action. Several cannot. Shipping insurers and owners are already signaling the possibility of withdrawing from Venezuelan ports if boarding operations expand¹³. Maduro will frame that as economic suffocation; Washington will frame it as sanctions doing their intended work. Ordinary Venezuelans will feel it as tightening scarcity.

Even geopolitically, the ripples widen quickly. Oil that was quietly moving to Cuba or Asia now travels under the shadow of interdiction. Guyana, an emerging producer in the middle of its own territorial dispute with Venezuela, suddenly finds its flag entangled in a confrontation it did not choose¹⁴. Regional navies, already wary of being pulled into great-power contests, now face the prospect of contested boardings within their exclusive economic zones. The Caribbean—never far from geopolitical pressure—has just been reminded how quickly commercial shipping can become a proxy battlefield.

The legal debate will continue in journals and courtrooms, but the operational reality is simple: a U.S. boarding in international waters is both a declaration of capability and an invitation to others to respond in kind. It is not piracy. It is not war. But it is not routine. It signals a willingness to enforce sanctions not by financial leverage alone but by physical intervention—a shift that reshapes the calculus of every state relying on shadow fleets and opaque shipping networks to survive sanctions.

**Once sanctions become kinetic, the line between economic pressure and coercive force begins to erode.**

The question that hovers over the _Skipper_ is not whether the United States had a legal rationale; it did. The question is whether the world wants to live in a maritime system defined by unilateral interdictions tied to national sanctions regimes rather than multilateral authority. The tanker was stateless, but the implications are not. When the law falters, precedent fills the void, and precedent has a long memory.

Somewhere, another captain will now hesitate before approaching Venezuela’s coast. Another insurer will adjust a risk model. Another government—perhaps one aligned with Washington today, perhaps not tomorrow—will study this operation and consider how similar logic might enable its own seizures under the banner of domestic law. That is the quiet power of a single boarding in the dark: it changes what future actors think they are allowed to do.

And the next time ropes drop onto a tanker’s deck, the stakes may be higher than one disputed cargo of heavy crude.

***

## **Bibliography**

1. Reuters. “Guyana Says U.S. Seized Tanker in International Waters After Fake Flag Use.” December 12, 2025. Confirms vessel was outside Venezuelan territorial waters and fraudulently used Guyana’s flag.

2. The Guardian. “Venezuela Accuses U.S. of Piracy After Tanker Seizure.” December 11, 2025. Details Venezuela’s official statement labeling the operation “shameless piracy.”

3. United Nations. UNCLOS, Part VII (Articles 101–102). Defines piracy and clarifies that state actors acting under government orders cannot commit piracy.

4. U.S. Treasury, OFAC. “Sanctions on Venezuelan and Iranian Oil Network Including Tanker _Adisa_ (Skipper).” 2022. Documents prior sanctions on the vessel and its alleged financing links.

5. U.S. Department of Justice. “Forfeiture Warrant Issued for Sanctioned Oil Transport Vessel.” December 2025. States that a federal seizure warrant covered the vessel or cargo.

6. U.S. Naval Institute News. “Southern Spear Task Force Intercepts Sanctioned Tanker Off Venezuelan Coast.” December 10, 2025. Describes U.S. operational framework and boarding forces.

7. International Maritime Organization. “High Seas Interdiction Parameters Under UNCLOS.” 2020. Explains legal bases for boarding vessels, including stateless ships.

8. BBC News. “Grace 1 Seizure Raises Questions Over Legality of EU Sanctions Enforcement.” July 2019. Covers concerns that Britain stretched international law by applying EU sanctions to non-EU ships.

9. U.S. Department of Defense. “Navy SEALs Recover Libyan Oil Tanker _Morning Glory_.” March 17, 2014. Details precedent-setting high-seas recovery operation.

10. Financial Times. “Iran Seizes British and Greek Tankers in Gulf Retaliation.” July 2019 and May 2022. Explains retaliatory seizure pattern triggered by sanctions confrontations.

11. Wall Street Journal. “U.S. Quietly Diverts Iranian Oil Shipments Using Civil Forfeiture.” 2020–2023. Provides background on prior U.S. interdictions under forfeiture law.

12. OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report. “Venezuela Production Update.” November 2025. Documents the approximate 900,000 bpd output.

13. Lloyd’s List. “Shipping Insurers Reassess Risks After U.S. Tanker Seizure.” December 2025. Notes increased wariness among insurers and owners about Venezuelan calls.

14. Stabroek News (Guyana). “Guyana Notified U.S. Operation After Tanker Fraudulently Used Its Flag.” December 12, 2025. Describes Guyana’s reaction and regional implications.
